column20: I mapped an area in the Franciscan melange as part of my Ph.D. thesis.  I guess I was pretty sheltered (or naive, or both), but I saw nothing gendered about calling the blocks of resistant material "knockers"  (this term's use in this context was pretty standard in the 1970s). When I started teaching (no longer in California), one of my colleagues objected strongly to the term "knocker" and only then did I understand that it had another context.  He was disappointed, I think, that I wasn't horrified and also wasn't willing to take on the task of removing the term from the entire geologic lexicon.

column26:
Thankfully, it's been many years since I saw a talk at a professional meeting that featured (non-relevant) images of scantily clad women, but I'm old enough to remember those and realistic enough to guess that they haven't disappeared entirely.

One of my first memories from a national meeting (1970,  I think) was seeing a panel of men speaking at one of the sessions and complaining that their wives had suddenly started objecting to their being gone in the field for 6 months at a time. 

I guess I could add that as an undergrad I was treated just like all of the other students.  There were 2 women (of 6 total) in my graduating class.  When I got to graduate school, it was a bit of a shock to be in an environment where gender was noticed and some casual sexual comments were made, though not necessarily directed at any woman in particular - just part of the atmosphere.  I didn't experience any sexism from the faculty or the other students, but in at least one incident off campus, I was dismissed as a source of geological information because my research partner (a guy who wasn't there) was clearly seen as the only expert.  

Another thing I could add is:  There were no tenured or tenure-track women faculty in the geology grad program at that time.  Towards the end of my grad school days, a group of us formulated a survey about gender perceptions and distributed it to at least the faculty and perhaps the grad students.  We were invited to meet with the department chair.  It was one of the first times that I felt the potential power of a group of women - 15-20 sitting on the floor of the office.  We clearly made the chair very uncomfortable, and I think that was a good thing, even though I now have second thoughts about the wisdom of sending out that survey   and even though it took even more years for a woman faculty member to be hired on tenure track.
